edu.illinois.masalzr2.gui

Class Stamp

  • java.lang.Object
    • edu.illinois.masalzr2.gui.Stamp
  • All Implemented Interfaces:
    java.io.Serializable

    public class Stamp
extends java.lang.Object
implements java.io.Serializable
    A model class used to define simple graphics options to be applied to JLabel or JButtons, both found in the javax.swing package.

    There are two characteristics that are manipulated by stamps:
    - The JLabel or JButton's border
    - The JLabel's or JButton's text

    The border is defined by an integer value that is a multiple of some combination of the first four prime numbers 2,3,5,7 (1 is not considered a prime). Each prime factor marks a different side of the border to be included as noted below when multiplied to the border value: 
      
              2 - NORTH
              _ 
  WEST - 7   |_|   3 - EAST
  
              5 - SOUTH
    For example, to create a JLabel or JButton with only a NORTH and SOUTH border, apply a Stamp with a border int value = 2x5 = 10. To include an EAST border, multiply the value by 3 to get 2 x 5 x 3 = 10 x 3 = 30.

    A value of 1 defines that there is no border.

    The text characteristics are handled with two values, are char called the engraving and the int called the style. A char is used because, typically in a game of Monopoly, the board tiles are only large enough to hold one character at a time. The style value defines whether or not the engraving is italicized, bolded, or underlined in much the same was as the border value where the primes used are the first three (2, 3, and 5) and define the style in the way below:

    2 - Underline
    3 - Italics
    5 - Bold

    A value of 1 defines an engraving of no styles. Generally recommended to use a bold (5) style as is very small on the board and thus can be difficult to see otherwise.

    FOOT NOTE FOR THE MATHEMATICALLY INTRIGUED
    A non-sequitur here, this design choice was inspired by the Fundamental Theorem of Arithmetic which states that "every integer greater than 1 either is prime itself or is the product of a unique combination of prime numbers" which guarantees that each border and style combination is defined if only the above primes are used and are used only once
    Author:
    Miguel Salazar
    See Also:

      • Stamp

        public Stamp(char e,
             int s,
             int bint)
        A fully fleshed out Stamp that applied a border, engraving, and style
        Parameters:
        e - Any char value. Preferably UTF-8 compatible
        s - int value that is a multiple of 1,2,3, or 5. Defines the engraving's Italics, Bolded, and Underlined status
        bint - short for Border int, this is the value that defines the border

      • validateStyle

        public static boolean validateStyle(int s)
        Validates that the style value is some multiple of 1,2,3, or 5
        Parameters:
        s - int value style candidate. This STATIC method does not apply the style to any object.
        Returns:
        boolean - true if valid, false if not

      • validateBorder

        public static boolean validateBorder(int b)
        Validates that the passed border value is some multiple of 1,2,3,5, or 7
        Parameters:
        b - int value border candidate. This STATIC method does not apply the style to any object.
        Returns:
        boolean - true if valid, false if not

      • engraveLabel

        public void engraveLabel(javax.swing.JLabel label)
        Engraves the passed JLabel with ONLY the engraving char value and the appropriate stylizations. Does not apply the border
        Parameters:
        label - JLabel - the JLabel to apply the stamp to.

      • makeBorder

        public javax.swing.border.Border makeBorder()

        Returns:
        Border - the generated MatteBorder based on the border value

      • makeBorder

        public static javax.swing.border.Border makeBorder(int b)
        Validates, develops, and then returns the border An empty border is returned when the border value is invalid
        Parameters:
        b - int value that defines the border
        Returns:
        Border - the border object to apply

      • setBorder

        public void setBorder(int b)
        Validates and then updates the border value ONLY IF valid. The border is otherwise untouched if not valid
        Parameters:
        b - the desired value to set border
